physicalObject: large silver Apple iMac computer monitor
proxyLocation: standing on the rear left side of the desk
utilizationMethod: Pinch the lower right corner of the aluminum bezel between thumb and index finger, angle the monitor edge downward, and tap the edge lightly onto the desk surface as though stabbing food

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A fork is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will pick up the fork with a precision-to-power hybrid grip: thumb and index finger oppose on the narrow handle faces while the other fingers wrap around for stability. Typical motions include (1) stabbing downward into food using small wrist and elbow flexion, (2) slight prying or twisting to secure the bite, and (3) lifting toward the mouth while supinating the forearm ~90° so the tines become horizontal. Contact is concentrated along the pads of the thumb, index, and middle fingers. The fork offers minimal inertia, so the haptic sensation is mainly its cool, hard, polished metal surface and the thin rectangular outline of the handle transitioning to four thin prongs. When the user pierces food the fork momentarily resists then penetrates, transmitting small vibration through the rigid handle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A fork is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will pick up the fork with a precision-to-power hybrid grip: thumb and index finger oppose on the narrow handle faces while the other fingers wrap around for stability. Typical motions include (1) stabbing downward into food using small wrist and elbow flexion, (2) slight prying or twisting to secure the bite, and (3) lifting toward the mouth while supinating the forearm ~90° so the tines become horizontal. Contact is concentrated along the pads of the thumb, index, and middle fingers. The fork offers minimal inertia, so the haptic sensation is mainly its cool, hard, polished metal surface and the thin rectangular outline of the handle transitioning to four thin prongs. When the user pierces food the fork momentarily resists then penetrates, transmitting small vibration through the rigid handle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual fork would be used for dining activities
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: A knife is relatively lightweight but has some mass.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a flat and elongated shape about 0.8-1 inch wide, and roughly 2-3mm thick.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel the surface as smooth and polished like stainless steel.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The knife is grasped with either a precision pinch (thumb against side of handle, index finger extended along the spine) for controlled spreading/cutting, or a light power grip when cutting firmer items. Users perform a downward press combined with a short fore-arm sawing motion, pivoting at the wrist. Contact zones: thumb pad, side of index finger, and middle-ring finger curls. The blade’s edge meets food and plate—providing intermittent tactile resistance and micro-vibrations that travel through the stiff metallic handle. The object is lightweight, so momentum changes are quick; stopping the stroke gives an immediate halt without noticeable lag.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the spoon similarly to a fork—thumb and index finger pinch the flat handle faces while remaining fingers cradle underneath. Interaction pattern: dip into liquid/soft food with a forward, slight downward arc, then lift and rotate the wrist into a supinated (palm-up) orientation for delivery to the mouth. The bowl of the spoon introduces a subtle torque due to the weight of any contained food, so users subconsciously modulate grip force. Haptic feedback includes a smooth, cold metal feel, a shallow concave outline at the distal end, and occasional tapping vibrations when the spoon contacts a bowl or plate rim.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the spoon similarly to a fork—thumb and index finger pinch the flat handle faces while remaining fingers cradle underneath. The bowl of the spoon introduces a subtle torque due to the weight of any contained food, so users subconsciously modulate grip force. Haptic feedback includes a smooth, cold metal feel, a shallow concave outline at the distal end, and occasional tapping vibrations when the spoon contacts a bowl or plate rim.
